comment: Long finish. Light on the palate. Golden color. Honey on the nose. Burns on the back of the tongue
Best Irish on the market today revitalizing the pot still.
For the price point this one is a damn fine whiskey.  Great nose and it certainly reminds you of what a great whiskey should taste like.  I'll certainly snag a bottle as soon as I can.

My first Irish whiskey. Maybe one of the smoothest whiskeys I have ever drank. A hint of scotch flavor that fades fast into a touch of sweet bourbon flavor and fruit then a nice long smooth finish. Nice easy to drink whiskey.
Very spicey and knocked you back, until I added a touch of water, then it became alive

Fantastic cereal notes on the nose, and the palate brings so much more! Sweetness, citrus and the return of those cereral notes and the proofing is just right with a slight burn on the back of the palate. Great Irish whisky. Highly recomended.
Jim Murray rates this above the Readbreast 12, but although they have similar flavours, I prefer the Readbreast. A great pot-still though.

This is a very exciting Single Pot Still. Beautiful ex-bourbon influence, excellently aged with a vanilla return from the oak. Perfect ABV, mature cereal and still lively and fresh. Rich. Silky, spice finish with cream. Sparkles on the tongue. Redbreast has competition.
Really love Powers. Not even close to RedBreast( but very few are lol) but it is at the top of my Irish list . Smooth, vanilla, nice body and finish . Great dram
Really enjoying this one. It has everything you would expect from a pot still and feels exceptionally smooth in the mouth. Loads of banana and cereal.

Great finish, but a really strong nose that overpowers (no pun intended). I compare it to yellow spot, which I shouldn't, but even though it's a smooth whiskey the nose is very alcoholic. Hopefully it with smooth out over the life of the bottle.
4.25. So good. Vanilla and caramel. Spicy goodness.  Woody. Yum. Full bodied, a bit of a sweet finish. 2nd time 7/17 4.5. Good stuff.

[LOOK] Light, golden [NOSE] Shortbread cookies, bread pudding rum sauce, butter, golden raisins, wildflowers [PALATE] Roasted peanuts, honey, chocolate, hazelnuts, vanilla, nut brittles, roast apple [FINISH] Short, sweet becomes dry Masala, oaky [MOUTHFEEL] Light, white wine, crisp, bright

At the Irish bar in Connecticut where I always seek out for their Fish and Chips with an ale/stout or two.  Peruse the shelf to determine what I have afterwards and Powers 12 is there and, since I never tasted, took advantage of the opportunity.

Nose is sweet honey, vanilla, banana and cereal.  A good Irish whiskey aroma.  Arrives surprisingly hot.  Wood dominates the palate.  Nutmeg, sugar, oak are all blended in a thin body.  The dram does sweeten over time (15-20 minutes) with a touch of water.  A bitter and woody finish that does last for a good length of time.

This has a lovely, sweet nose and to a great contrast, a dry oaky and spicy palate.  This feels younger than a 12 year; I was surprised somewhat by that spiciness/bite.  A teaspoon of water and patience tones the Power’s harshness down.  Maybe I prefer my Irish whiskey’s sweeter (ala Green Spot/Red Breast), but, give it time and water and you have a decent Irish dram.  [85/100][Tasted: 11/7/16 @ Vaughan’s]
Nice smooth oak, heavy vanilla, maple on the nose and the palet

Having really enjoyed the Gold Label, the NAS version, I was intrigued to try the older version. I am struck with a fast succession of overlapping flavours like fenil, herbs, spice, tangy bitterness, rye and leather, the flavours then drop and then reform: mint coffee, smoke and then a peppery, smooth, honeyed, finish, some oak notes and finally, a subtle, lingering taste of candy floss. Granted the finish is longer, but it tastes younger, rather discordant, with an off bitter and tangy set of flavours paired with strange, excessive sweetness. It's a bizarre mix of bourbon flavours and Irish whiskey, too styles at times close, but here seemingly on different planets that should never be destined to meet.

Nose: sherry, some oak, vanilla

Taste: full, oily, sweet, fruity, and some oak.

Aftertaste: short with some pepper

This is a great 12 year old whisky. It's thick, rich, fruity, and smoooth!

I must own this bottle for my own collection. Incredibly oily and full bodied with a huge Carmel presence. Straight out of the bottle it's spicy with some light fruit elements, but I don't find any sherry inflict within this. Over time it softens up but still retains quality. I would like to come back to this again, but the first impression is killer!
Similar to Green Spot but with more complex end
Fantastic value - earthy, cinnamon, chocolate and toffee on the nose. Soft vanilla spice on the pallets with sweet fruits. Long finish of sweet oak.
Just outstanding and one of the best Irish whiskies in my own personal opinion.
Solid whiskey with vanilla notes; it is a bit harsh up front bite

dunkles Braun mit süßen Aromen, besonders Karamell. Initial sehr süß wie Nachtisch, dann fruchtig(Traube/Rosine) mit klarer Schokolade. Erinnert an Rittersport Rum-Traube-Nuss. Süß genug um einen Whisky zu ersetzten.

Fruity & vanilla
Nose, sweet fruity
Taste, spice
Finish, long. I like it
If you’re looking THE must-own Irish pot still to add to your collection, the Johns Lane is it.
Harsh initially, but I’m trying to blame it on the warm Israeli weather. Nice vanilla and honey notes, some spices
Caramel, honey and that familiar pot still spice. Probably a hint of sherry. To me, this tastes very similar to Yellow Spot, but it is significantly less expensive. A good dram and a good value.

The original Powers Distillery was located on John's Lane just off Thomas Street - in Dublin's Liberties (where the best whiskey was invented). This whiskey matured in ex-bourbon barrels and finished off for a small amount of time in ex-sherry casks.

 Nose - Distinct cocoa and mocha overtones with hints of dried apricots, orange peel and marshmallow.
Taste - Soft and smooth. Crisp and spicy - element of bittersweet fruit, marmalade and toffee apples. Velvety texture
Finish - Chocolatey with some dusty oakiness

Best whiskety Powers has top offer. I bought on recommendation of fine bar man in Peruke & Periwig bar, Dublin, having spent a lonely afternoon there with my missus.

(credit to published reviews - on which I built mine)

Nose: Complex malty cereal aromas conjoined spectacularly with old oak and a little dark honey and leather. Dark stewed fruits of an unexpected variety - flambée pineapple, prunes, dates and banana, sprinkled with tumeric. Rich, austerely sweet, subtle and relaxing. A very good nose. [The dry-glass aroma is simple brown sugar with an oaky hint].

Palate: Sweet and luscious oily arrival against a backdrop of oak. The development brings out complex flavours that are balanced with meticulous precision. The initial sweetness settles down to a dignified semi-sweet character with vanilla, blood orange, dark chocolate, sultanas, barley sugar, ginger, hot cinnamon, allspice, black cherry and dry sherry. The texture is full and poised but never loses a certain crisp freshness. There is a warm dusky heat in the late palate as it leads into the finish that is close to sublime.

Finish: Long. Oily and fruity, with a lingering sweetness and an elusive hint of mint or anise in the aftertaste

Bold but refined and with impeccable balance. This is wonderful whiskey and great value for the price - I don't know what more I can say.

It is best taken neat if you wish to experience the full force of its personality, but if preferred it can take a dash of water to open and soften the experience. The nose is slightly diminished in the process, but the palate is thrown wide open. I'd recommend having two drams, one neat and one watered, so you can have the best of both worlds.

"Very Good" : 4 stars
Lovely. Was a bit pissed when I drank it but loved it regardless.

There's a reason this is so well liked. I'm ready to open my second bottle for 2018. Along with a few others like Cooper's Croze from Jameson and all of the Spots from Mitchell & Sons (especially the Green), this level of whiskey is a perfect fit for me in terms of price/reward. Along with once-a-year bottles of Midleton Very Rare Irish and Elijah Craig 18 yr. old mixed in, life is very good. Now to start tasting the Smoke and Peat soon. Saints preserve me!

$57.99 USD in PA.

Regular old blended Powers is a good, cheap-n-cheerful Irish blend.This is an entirely different story. A pure pot still offering, this is what I wish Redbreast were. Full, oily, creamy, brimming over with fruit and spice and toasty oak. A really great dram.
Great pot still drop. The alcohol doesn't quite integrate well with the rest of the whisky though as it has a bit of a bite to it. A bit hot for the 46%. Redbreast 15 at same abv is better balanced

Nose: Honey, caramel 
Palate: woody with more caramel and some vanilla.
Finish: gingery 

the bourbon barrels really come out in this whiskey - definitely can tastes it's relation to  their gold label
Great stuff. Nose of caramel, vanilla, and spices. Great among single malt drinkers and bourbon drinkers.
Surprise it’s better than you thought. Vanilla and deep sugar Carmel. Mmmmm quick think of something smart to say.....mmmmmmm

Powers packs a sweet, powerful Irish punch! In my opinion, this is nowhere near as refined as Redbreast though. The honey are a little overpowering and you don’t get that much oak or fruit for balance. 90

I previously worked very close to John's Lane, the site of the long-gone Powers  distillery in Dublin.  In fact I worked on Roe Lane which is the site of the long-gone Roe & Co distillery.  That was once one of the largest distilleries in Dublin and now a brand resurrected by Diageo, who also have plans to build a new distillery on their Guinness lot.   In any case, while I haven't yet tasted DIageo's new fare, I have enjoyed Midleton's output and this is one of my favourite Irish whiskeys.
    
    A little bit of water brings out the best in this, in my opinion, but it is still damn fine neat.  The nose is tiramisu, chocolate, and toffee with a similar smooth taste and the characteristic spiciness of a pot still whiskey.
    
    I first received a miniature bottle of it in an excellent gift pack that included Redbreast 12, Green Spot, and Barry Crockett Legacy. Although not the standout of the four  it is one of my go-to drams on an all too rare night out in Dublin.  An easy 4 stars - often hitting 4.5 depending on my mood and the quantities imbibed.
Don’t even remember other then it was good.
"Is anybody home?" Little to no smell. Vanilla oaky palate (mild) but short lived finish.

Now that i’m further into the bottle...here’s an updated tasting. This whiskey is just simply an amazing example of the wonders of pot still spirits. 

Nose: Rich malt, milk chocolate, vanilla and caramel cream, apple turnovers with sugar icing, and then the pot still comes
In with hints of copper and nitro lacquer, shortbread cookie and spiced pears. 
Palate: entry is sweet and oily with a little peppery spice on the sides of the tongue. Warm alcohol burn down the back of the throat. Apples and brown sugar, clove, cinnamon, cherry liquor, bourbon like vanilla, chocolate fudge, pear schnapps (Williams), 
Finish: slightly tannic and drying, cocoa, cracked pepper, flambeed pears and rum over crumb cake,  vanilla and toffee.
solid Irish that is less sweet. still green apple when adding H2O. I could own a bottle...
Smooth mouthfeel slightly hot on the finish
Lots of early vanilla, strong alcohol finish

Nose: fresh tique, ground pepper, sea breeze. 
Taste: spice, great depth, dark woods, salt toffee.

I have to admit I was disappointed by this one. The reviews looked so promising. I saw it in a bar and thought I’d try before I sunk the money into a bottle. 

Nose is aggressive. A little water rounded it off and gave off a note not unlike Honey Nut Cheerios, if you could get drunk off those. Taste was pleasant enough. Typical single pot still maltiness. Not a bad pour by any means, and I would happily drink it again if someone offered it, but not something for my home bar I think.

Surprised I hadn’t heard much about this one. My Green Spot is on it’s last legs and I picked this up to follow it. The Powers is similar to Green Spot but just a little darker on the fruits, while coming across as more refined, buttery, and elegant. Beautiful Irish whisky that flies under the radar.

Here’s an updated tasting now that i’m further into the bottle. Let me just start with Irish Whiskies are not my favorite in general. However, This Power’s edition is just absolutely delicious

Nose: Rich malt, milk chocolate, vanilla and caramel cream, apple turnovers with sugar icing, and then the pot still comes
In with hints of copper and nitro lacquer, shortbread cookie and spiced pears. 
Palate: entry is sweet and oily with a little peppery spice on the sides of the tongue. Warm alcohol burn down the back of the throat. Apples and brown sugar, clove, cinnamon, cherry liquor, bourbon like vanilla, chocolate fudge, pear schnapps (Williams), 
Finish: slightly tannic and drying, cocoa, cracked pepper, flambeed pears and rum over crumb cake,  vanilla and toffee.
If you like Irish whisky because you associate it with smoothness, then you'd definitely enjoy a dram of this thing. It's a great value whisky, and delivers quite well
Probably the best of the Powers line.  Robust nose and forefront, but a silky back of the mouth finish that's just a bit warm.

Nose is sweet, floral. Very light Sherry.  Initial is light honey, with palate of alcohol and a wood (not oak?) mixed with a tart taste.   Finish is back to light honey and alcohol.   When I put alcohol twice in a description it's a pass.   Not sure how this ranks so high.  :)

The nose is a lot of fruit like apricot and apples. A clear vanilla note as well.

On palate it is smooth and sweet. The sweet is one of fruit juice - like apple juice. Along with some peaches and mangoes in it.

The finish is relatively short but a pleasant in cream and apples.
Green apple candy on the nose.  Chocolate and caramel taste and a smooth long finish.  Another home run from Powers.
Kvalitní whisky, dřevitá. Ale  není můj typ...

Had this as part of a flight. Jameson Black Barrell, Jon Lane and Readbreast 12. I fully expected to like Redbreast the best but after going through the 2nd time I finally had to admit that my preconceived notions were wrong. I won't waste your time with my tasing note. Just know that I went and bought a bottle the next day.
Wow....  buy the bottle then buy another!

Aroma of a fruit salad. Fruit with a hint of vanilla in the first taste. Adding water really smooths it out. 

Not bad but not worth the price.
Mild honey and caramel nose; sherry, vanilla, spice, raisins; a little sweet and a decent burn; finishes with leather and dried fruit
Beautiful golden color. Very smooth. Some caramel with honey flavors. Not too sweet.
